data.text: I have to tell you I don't wear a helmet. Shock horror! I will now get the usual hate mail from those who think helmets keep.them safe. They might, they might not. There is no evidence either way. If you ride off road in rough terrain I suspect a helmet will help prevent injury but again there just isn't evidence. I have been riding for 70 years. Still ride most days on road. I am always at risk of serious injury or death from vehicles that come too close, too fast and a tiny bit of polystyrene on my head will make little or no difference. I wear a high viz vest. I sometimes do wear a helmet because it's a platform for a very visible camera that does seem to keep cars away, but mostly I find a helmet uncomfortable and I get neck pain, not helped by extra weight on the head. I have flashing bright lights front and rear. I never race against others or the clock. I don't put myself in danger by getting so exhausted I cannot think clearly. I often walk through dangerous junctions. I often give way to vehicles but sometimes it's safer to demand my space...I do all manner of things to stay alive...wearing a helmet isn't one of them.

data.text: Allow me to provide some points into your, "everyone must wear a helmet because safety science says so". It is true that if I wear rubber boots when walking I am better protected against being struck by lightening. Being struck by lightening is about the same odds as death from cycling WHEN NO MOTOR VEHICLE IS INVOLVED! So you want me to wear a helmet, first because you think they protect...they don't. And second because you think I might make a mistake that results in injury. But why pick out cycling, I could slip walking. Should I wear protection for everything? A cycle helmet only protects the top of the head. What are the odds, first falling second landing on top of my head? Shouldn't I protect the whole skull...it makes no sense not to given you think I need protecting. If I land feet first at speed the shock will transmit through my backbone and cause brain injury, a well known fact from people jumping great heights landing feet first. And what about the negatives. Wearing a helmet heats the head causing tiredness and lack of attention leading to accidents. Finally where no motor vehicles are involved cycle injuries are so rare (for people using a bike to travel, not sport riders competing and putting themselves in dangerous situations...even then deaths are rare) there is no need to wear a helmet. Please wear one if it makes you feel better but the quotes you give of safety improvements are a fiction.

It just so happened it turned out fine for them but plenty of examples out there of people it did not work for. Forgetting all that, even if you ride perfectly safely at all times by Not going too fast, not being tired, walking across dangerous junctions; we cannot account for the stupidity of other people and their actions. As an example, I was doing about 5-10km an hour going up a very short hill when an electric bike riding down rode straight into me knocking us both off bikes with a Big Bang. (I would not have died in this example without helmet but would have been more hurt.) Easy to imagine situations where helmets do save serious injuries. data.text: Here in NZ it is compulsory to ride with a helmet, and honestly it has saved my life around 5 times now. However, I hear you re: sun visors - the ones in the hats aren’t that great, and I am super pale and freckled and burn REALLY easily. So. I have taken to buying one of those weird sun visor things that are like a baseball cap with no “top”, and attaching it to the inside of my helmet with cable ties ( I thread it the through the inside of the visor so that the plastic of the cable tie isn’t against my skin). It works great, doesn’t flap down in wind, and I chose a sports/tennis visor which has some fabric built in that stops sweat from running down my face. My head stays cool and protected, and I change it out periodically. In mid summer I sometimes use o e of those hats that has fabric attached to cover your neck, but chop the “top” out of the hat so I don’t get too hit. Works great 🙂
data.author: Penny Aspin

data.text: I found that brims intended for use on hard hats have worked well for me.
data.author: Steve Pustell

data.text: I often wear a hat under my helmet, works for me.
data.author: John Bosley
